title: Can bail be included in a bankruptcy filing?
question: I am paying bail for a family member and they are also paying a separate bail (2 different cases) to which I am a co-signer. If they are convicted, can I claim both bail payments on a bankruptcy?
answers: Bankruptcy law requires you to disclose all assets and debts. If you owe money to a bail bondsmen, it must be listed even though it may be secured and possibly non-dischargeable.

The first question is what does the bond cover? There are several varieties that do not involve cash. If you posted bail that creates a lien on some property that you own, then the question is can you avoid the “lien” for lack of value in a bankruptcy case? A criminal bail bond lien would be treated like any other lien or mortgage on your home. If there is not enough value to cover the lien, then it can and will be avoided in a bankruptcy proceeding leaving you with the property.

So if the bond is simply a personal guarantee , then it is an unsecured debt much like any other. If you later file for bankruptcy, the debt must come under some provision of Bankruptcy Code Section 523 to survive. Courts have held that the bond is not a debt owed to a governmental authority under Section 523(a)(7), but is merely a private contract where a third party pays the government on a guarantee of debt. So the bond debt would be dischargeable.

I'm moving this to the bankruptcy forum, where you're more likely to get the right answer.

I think you're confused.

It appears you're paying a bail bond company, not paying bail.

Bail is an amount posted with the court to guarantee a criminal defendant's appearance. If the defendant shows up, you get the money back at the end of the case. You can't pay bail in installments.

A bail bond is like an insurance policy, which usually costs ten percent of the full bail amount. Many bail companies agree to time payments.

If the defendant doesn't show up, then the bail bond company is on the hook for the full amount. That's why they use bounty hunters; it's cheaper for them to find people who run than to pay the full bail amount.

I believe a bail bond contract is like any other time payment agreement, such as a credit card, but I only practice criminal law, so I'm not sure. A bankruptcy attorney would be able to give you a more informed answer.
